text: Hey <@UPM5604VC>.  I work at a  non-profit too. As Taran mentioned one of the basic differences I would point out is the fact that the content aimed for and created follows a more storytelling approach, delivering value.  But I believe it also has to do with the industry and the non-profit itself. What kind of content have they already created on their blog and website?

text: Hi all, I'm redoing my resume and I'm curious how you handle listing tools and software on your resume. I decided to remove the section listing all the social media platforms I can use because I'm no longer focused on social media in my career path. Since I'm mid-career, I'm proficient in many project management and collab tools, analytics programs, design programs, and email marketing tools. It's a lot to fit in a resume, but they're all relevant to the roles I'm interested in. Do employers need to see all these, or is there a better way to convey this?

elements.text: Hi all, I'm redoing my resume and I'm curious how you handle listing tools and software on your resume. I decided to remove the section listing all the social media platforms I can use because I'm no longer focused on social media in my career path. Since I'm mid-career, I'm proficient in many project management and collab tools, analytics programs, design programs, and email marketing tools. It's a lot to fit in a resume, but they're all relevant to the roles I'm interested in. Do employers need to see all these, or is there a better way to convey this?

text:
If you can find out which tools your prospective employer uses, then highlight those (or very similar ones). You can get this info from former employees or even current ones if they're willing to share.

There's also tech out there that can scan through organizations and find the tech stacks they use: <https://www.saleswingsapp.com/how-to/7-tools-to-find-companies-using-specific-technology/>

Usually used by salespeople, but job hunters can also take advantage!
